_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Clearwater Paper Corporation owns and operates a large Bleached Paper Board mill in Augusta, Georgia. The mill is fully integrated: from incoming wood to Kraft pulping process to coated final product.

All aspects of safety and environmental stewardship are top mill and corporate priorities as stated in the Corporate EHS Policy: 
     Vision- We will be responsible members of the communities where we live and work.
     Principles of Excellence - We respect and protect the environment, and the health and safety of our fellow employees.  We are good citizens who actively participate in our communities.  
     Corporate Goals - Accident-free workplace, continuous improvement in environmental performance, elimination of environmental incidents, and active involvement in communities where we live and work.
The Company intends to comply with all applicable health and safety and environmental protection laws.

It is the Policy of the Clearwater Paper Corporation Augusta Mill, to provide a safe working environment for all its employees.  To deal with Mill Emergency situations that might arise, the Augusta Mill provides an Emergency Action Plan to allow expedient and safe response in dealing with such Mill Emergency situations.
When the Emergency Response Team is activated, a Mill Emergency is deemed to exist and the emergency response shall be controlled through the mill's Incident Command System under the command of the Emergency Response Team Incident Commander.

The Mill makes updates to its safety systems and procedures as the need arises.

The only regulated substance used at the mill is chlorine dioxide, which is manufactured on-site for bleaching of wood pulp. 

The worst case scenario in this RMP assumes the release of the contents of the largest storage tank.  The entire quantity of the 1% chlorine dioxide solution is assumed to spill instantaneously into a diked area and evaporate at a rate determined by the model.  The worst case atmospheric conditions are assum

ed in this scenario.  The offsite consequence analysis provided in the 2023 resubmission was performed with the DEGADIS Model.

The most likely and alternative release scenarios were evaluated using the DEGADIS model. These scenarios involve a release from a storage tank and process pipeline between the solution storage area and one of the bleach plants. The alternative release scenario assumes that the discharge would last for 40 minutes before the mill's Emergency Response Team could suit up and stop the flow. Atmospheric conditions are assumed to be normal.  The potential impacted area includes receptors such as residences and other industrial sites. This scenario is very unlikely because the loss of flow would trigger alarms in the bleach plant, immediate investigation would ensue and the system would be shut down in much less than 40 minutes. Also, the Emergency Response Team would be deluging any spill with water to lessen the impact of the release.

Chlorine dioxide is also covered under the mill's OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  Enhanced training for both operations and maintenance personnel is in place for all of the covered processes as well as the Distributed Control System alarm systems to alert operations should the covered systems develop leaks or other major faults.

Training and preparation for a release include on-site emergency response teams for each shift, trained to the Hazardous Materials (Haz-Mat) technician level. These teams receive annual 40 hour training at an off-site fire academy and drill monthly under the direction of the in-house fire chief. There is a site emergency response plan, emergency operations center and on-site medical department.

The mill is well prepared should an emergency occur. In addition, the culture of continuous improvement will provide opportunity for improvement as technology advances in the areas of sensors and control devices that would enhance the day-to-day safety of these processes.
